answers.body:
java.time

In modern Java, use the java.time classes for all your date-time work.

LocalDate

No need to define your own class for a date (year, month, day). Use java.time.LocalDate.

Formatting pattern

Define a formatting pattern to match your inputs.

DateTimeFormatter f = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern( "MM/dd/uuuu" ) ;

Parse

Parse your input with appropriate formatter.

LocalDate date = LocalDate.parse( input , f ) ;

Trap for parsing exception to handle faulty input.

ISO 8601

Even better solution: Educate the publisher of your data about using only standard ISO 8601 formats when exchanging date-time values. The standard format for date is YYYY-MM-DD. The java.time classes use the standard formats by default.

LocalDate date = LocalDate.parse( "2025-01-23" ) ;

Extract

Extract the parts you desire.

int year = date.getYear() ;
Month month = date.getMonth() ;
int monthNumber = date.getMonthValue() ;
int day = date.getDayOfMonth() ;
DayOfWeek dow = date.getDayOfWeek() ;
